docs.lead_paragraph: By reducing costs and shedding troubled businesses, Oxford Health Plans appears to be reducing the losses that have plagued it over the last year. The managed care company said yesterday that it had lost $47 million, or 58 cents a share, for the quarter ended Sept. 30, on revenue of $1.2 billion. Having disappointed analysts last quarter when it reported a loss of $507.6 million, Oxford surprised them yesterday with significantly better-then-expected results. Wall Street had been expecting a per-share loss ranging from 65 cents to more than $1.

headline.main: Oxford Cuts Costs and Its Losses, but No Profits Are Expected Soon

docs.abstract: Oxford Health Plans appears to be reducing losses that have plagued it over last year by reducing costs and shedding troubled businesses; Oxford reports loss of $47 million for quarter ended Sept 30, on revenue of $1.2 billion; chief executive Dr Norman C Payson comments; chart; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut, a Republican, was elected on a promise to eliminate the state income tax, and didn't do it. He tried to slash the state budget, but retreated after protests from priests, pupils and park rangers. He was fined by the State Ethics Commission for accepting box seats at a Jimmy Buffett concert, his wife became a punch line when the state leased her a Chevrolet Suburban, and one of his children helped himself to surplus camping equipment at a state warehouse.

headline.main: A New Rowland Preaches Flexible, 'Fun' Republicanism

docs.abstract: Connecticut Gov John G Rowland, basking in 48-point lead in polls over his Democratic challenger Rep Barbara B Kennelly and 76 percent approval rating, contends voters are rewarding warm and flexible brand of Republicanism that he hopes someday to export beyond Connecticut; Rowland comments; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two days after New Jersey officials moved to take control of the state's fourth-largest health maintenance organization, the president of the company that had bought its medical centers was found dead at his home, apparently a suicide, the authorities said. Dr. Paul W. Frankel, 50, was president of Pinnacle Health Enterprises in New Brunswick, N.J., which stands to lose tens of millions of dollars on the 23 medical centers it recently bought from the financially troubled H.I.P. Health Plan of New Jersey.

headline.main: Executive in H.M.O. Deal Is Apparent Suicide

docs.lead_paragraph: It was the most indelible image of the 1994 gubernatorial campaign: a newspaper photograph of George E. Pataki being led, literally by the hand, through a crowded fund-raising dinner by his political patron, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato. Mr. Pataki's opponent, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, seized on the picture, using it in television ads, as Democrats derided the Republican candidate as ''an empty suit,'' the puppet on Mr. D'Amato's string. Mr. Pataki contributed to the image of himself as a cipher, running on a rail-thin platform of cutting taxes and restoring the death penalty, assiduously avoiding saying what else he would do if elected. Critics in both parties predicted that he would not amount to much.

headline.main: Pataki Defies Expectations And Becomes Quiet Force

docs.abstract: New York Gov Pataki, Republican derided by Democrats in 1994 campaign as cipher, has emerged as shrewd political operator expected to easily win re-election in heavily Democratic state; has surprised people by keeping expectations at minimum, allowing him to defy or exceed them; fuzziness of his public positions, once seen as weakness, has allowed him to get his way on some issues and reposition self to his advantage on others; table of biographical data; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Proposed regulations to help cut automobile insurance premiums 15 percent by cracking down on fraudulent medical claims are being criticized by medical lobbyists who say the regulations would result in some patients being denied necessary coverage. The regulations, which are expected to be adopted next month by the Department of Banking and Insurance, exempt from coverage some diagnostic tests for spinal injuries, and would establish a protocol for the treatment of neck and back injuries.

headline.main: Medical Lobbyists Fight Auto Insurance Proposal

docs.abstract: Medical lobbyists in New Jersey criticize proposed regulations to help cut automobile insurance premiums 15 percent by cracking down on fraudulent medial claims on ground that result would be that some patients would be denied necessary coverage (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a move that highlighted regulatory questions with health maintenance organizations, New Jersey officials have moved to take over the operation of H.I.P. Health Plan of New Jersey, after it appeared to be sliding into insolvency and was having problems paying its health care providers. In taking the relatively drastic step to rescue the state's fourth-largest H.M.O. and to insure that its 194,000 clients would continue to have health care coverage, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said through a spokesman that it was also time for the state to explore additional measures ''to create a safety net'' for health consumers in the state.

headline.main: State Control Is Proposed For an H.M.O. In New Jersey

docs.lead_paragraph: When asked to assess George E. Pataki's record as Governor, Tom Carroll, president of the conservative group Change-NY, asked: ''Which one? The Pataki of the first two years or the Pataki of the second two years?'' On a host of issues, like state spending, education and health care, there is a sharp difference between the conservative Republican Governor who took office promising to shrink government, and the moderate Mr. Pataki now running for re-election. But on what his aides say are his core issues, like tax cuts and crime, the Governor has been fairly consistent.

headline.main: Two Patakis: In 4 Years, Governor Has Pushed Issues Both Conservative and Moderate

docs.abstract: Article examines record of New York State Gov George Pataki on issues of taxes, spending and economy, crime, welfare, health care, education and environment (M)
